metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: The multi-scale observation experiment on evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces (MUSOEXE-12)-dataset of flux observation matrix (No.17 eddy covariance system) from Mar to Sep, 2012
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from site No.17 eddy covariance system (EC) in the flux observation matrix from 31 May to 17 September, 2012. The site (100.36972° E, 38.84510° N) was located in an orchard (apple tree) in Daman irrigation district, which is near Zhangye, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1559.63 m. The EC was installed at a height of 7 m; the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (CSAT3&EC150) was 0 m.
Raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Edire post-processing software (University of Edinburgh, http://www.geos.ed.ac.uk/abs/research/micromet/EdiRe/), including spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. Moreover, the observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC), which was proposed by Foken and Wichura [1996]: class 1 (level 0: Δst<30 and ITC<30), class 2 (level 1: Δst<100 and ITC<100), and class 3 (level 2: Δst>100 and ITC>100), representing high-, medium-, and low-quality data, respectively. In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 3% of the 30 min raw record; and (4) data were rejected at night when the friction velocity (u*) was less than 0.1 m/s. There were 48 records per day; the missing data were replaced with -6999. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m^3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m^3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (z/L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m^2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m^2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m^2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xlsx format.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2016) (for multi-scale observation experiment or sites information), Xu et al. (2013) (for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'eddy covariance system' in the context of data collection for evapotranspiration measurements?
Definition.Answer: An eddy covariance system is a data collection method used to measure the turbulent fluxes of heat, water vapor, and carbon dioxide between the land surface and the atmosphere. It involves the use of instruments such as an ultrasonic anemometer and a gas analyzer, which are typically mounted on a tower to capture high-frequency data on wind speed, temperature, and gas concentrations at a specific point. This method is particularly useful in evaluating the total fluxes of evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes.

Interpretation.Question: What are the challenges in using composite temperature separation approaches in arid regions for estimating evapotranspiration, and how might these be addressed through different data collection methods?
Interpretation.Answer: Composite temperature separation approaches face challenges in arid regions due to factors like image classification errors and atmospheric influence on radiation measurements. These challenges can be addressed by using high-resolution thermal cameras for component temperature estimation and by employing stable isotope techniques alongside traditional eddy covariance data to better capture the spatial variability and improve the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimates.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of effectively separating soil and canopy component temperatures in arid regions using composite temperature separation approaches?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in separating soil and canopy component temperatures in arid regions arise from image classification errors that vary with vegetation abundance, leading to soil pixels being misclassified as vegetation pixels. This results in overestimation of canopy temperature. Additionally, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance can introduce uncertainties, as can estimating the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the limited effectiveness of current composite temperature separation approaches in arid regions for estimating evapotranspiration components?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The limited effectiveness is primarily due to errors in derived component temperatures caused by image classification errors, especially when soil pixels are counted as vegetation pixels. This is compounded by uncertainties in atmospheric upwelling radiation, transmittance, and the estimation of incoming radiation transmittances through the canopy.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to accurately estimate surface fluxes in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Accurately estimating surface fluxes in such areas is challenging due to the incomplete energy balance closure of EC flux measurements with respect to available energy (Rn−G0). Uncertainty in surface-air temperature differences, errors in determining soil and vegetation component temperatures, and the strong advective environment add to the complexity, affecting the performance of models such as the TSEB model.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of implementing multiscale observation techniques in eco-hydrological research?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing multiscale observation techniques in eco-hydrological research can lead to a better understanding of eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces. It addresses the challenge of poor availability of multiscale observations by capturing data at hierarchically nested scales, thus allowing for more comprehensive analysis of interactions such as those between oasis and desert systems.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the use of high-resolution thermal cameras affect the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimations in agricultural areas?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of high-resolution thermal cameras can improve the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimations by providing precise soil and canopy component temperatures. This enhances the validation of evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration measurements, particularly when using models like the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model, even under strongly advective conditions in irrigated agricultural areas.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the main objective of establishing a multiscale dataset through the HiWATER experiment in an oasis-desert area?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goal of establishing the multiscale dataset through the HiWATER experiment is to address the challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface by obtaining multiscale and multidisciplinary data using instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the intended purpose of using a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers and other instruments in the HiWATER observation system?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended purpose of using a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers and other instruments in the HiWATER observation system is to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes and provide comprehensive data for understanding the interactions in an oasis-desert area, while ensuring data quality through careful calibration and processing.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are thermal camera images processed to estimate soil and canopy component temperatures in the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Thermal camera images are processed by classifying visible and NIR images into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. The soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures are extracted from the thermal images, and the thermal infrared temperatures are converted to radiation temperatures using incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and soil and canopy emissivities. Simulated radiometric temperatures are then validated against surface radiometric temperatures.

Enablement.Question: What instrumentation advancements and configurations enable the collection of multiscale and multidisciplinary eco-hydrological data in heterogeneous landscapes?
Enablement.Answer: The Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) utilizes instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales, including a superstation, eddy covariance towers, automatic meteorological stations, and eco-hydrological sensor networks. Additionally, hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing with LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and L-band microwave radiometers are used to collect multiscale and multidisciplinary data.

Enablement.Question: How do specific data processing techniques enable the improvement of data quality and accuracy in eddy covariance flux observations?
Enablement.Answer: Data processing techniques such as outlier removal, time delay correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density (WPL) correction enable the improvement of data quality and accuracy. Additionally, quality assessments based on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics are performed, and data is filtered by excluding instrument errors, precipitation effects, and high missing rate intervals.

Enablement.Question: What conditions and methodologies enable the reliable separation and estimation of soil and canopy component temperatures in the TSEB model?
Enablement.Answer: The TSEB model utilizes high-resolution thermal infrared cameras to observe soil and canopy component temperatures. The component temperatures are estimated using visible and NIR image classification into soil and canopy pixels, followed by extraction of directional brightness temperatures. These are then converted to radiative temperatures using atmospheric long-wave radiation and emissivities. Validation against surface radiometric temperatures ensures reliable separation and estimation.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be limitations in accurately estimating evapotranspiration using traditional one-source models in heterogeneous landscapes?
Expectation.Answer: One-source models combine the soil and vegetation components into a single source, which can be problematic in heterogeneous landscapes. These models do not account for the differences in temperature and resistance to energy exchange between soil and vegetation, leading to inaccuracies in surface evapotranspiration estimation.

Expectation.Question: What challenges are faced in the accurate separation of soil and canopy temperatures for evapotranspiration estimation, and how might these affect the outcomes?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges include image classification errors that vary with vegetation abundance, causing soil pixels to be misclassified as vegetation pixels. This results in an overestimation of canopy temperature, affecting the accuracy of latent heat flux estimations and the performance of models like TSEB in calculating evapotranspiration components.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the effectiveness of using multi-scale observations in capturing eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of multi-scale observations is crucial for capturing eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces. The HiWATER experiment, which incorporates hierarchically nested scales of instrumentation, addresses the challenge of upscaling these processes by providing comprehensive multiscale and multidisciplinary data. This approach is particularly effective in capturing the complex interactions within oasis-desert systems.

Judgmental.Question: How would you assess the challenges associated with obtaining accurate component temperatures for use in the Two-Source Energy Balance (TSEB) model, particularly in arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Obtaining accurate component temperatures for the TSEB model in arid regions poses significant challenges. Composite temperature separation approaches are limited due to factors such as image classification errors and the strong advective environment. These challenges can lead to overestimation of canopy temperatures and errors in energy flux estimations, which affect the model's accuracy.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how a dataset could be accurately collected in a heterogeneous landscape with varying soil and vegetation components.
Assertion.Answer: In a heterogeneous landscape, the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model can be applied to estimate evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration for areas covered with vegetation. The model considers the energy partition occurring both above the canopy and under the soil, allowing the mixed water vapor and heat to exit through the top of the canopy. Ground-based measurements, such as those from the eddy covariance (EC) system, can be used to validate the component temperatures and fluxes to ensure accurate data collection.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the techniques used to manage and filter raw observational data from sensors in such complex environmental studies.
Assertion.Answer: Raw observational data from sensors, such as from eddy covariance systems, are managed by using software like Edire to process and filter the data. This involves steps such as outlier removal, delay time correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, and density corrections (WPL). The data is also quality evaluated based on parameters like atmospheric stability and turbulence characteristics. Specific data filtering criteria include removing data during instrument errors, precipitation, high data loss rates, and weak turbulence conditions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline an approach to enhance data collection techniques for measuring evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes using remote sensing and ground-based methods.
Request/Directive.Answer: The field outlines utilizing the Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) which employs a combination of ground-based eddy covariance systems, automatic meteorological stations, and advanced remote sensing technologies such as LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, and thermal imagers. By arranging these instruments in hierarchically nested scales, researchers can effectively capture eco-hydrological processes across various landscapes, including oasis and desert systems. This approach allows for comprehensive multiscale data collection needed to accurately estimate evapotranspiration in such complex terrains.

Request/Directive.Question: Please evaluate the challenges faced in collecting multiscale eco-hydrological data and suggest potential solutions to overcome these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in collecting multiscale eco-hydrological data include the poor availability of observations across different scales and the complexity of heterogeneous surfaces. The HiWATER experiment addresses these issues through an extensive observation system that includes an eco-hydrological sensor network and remote sensing technologies. This setup allows for capturing detailed data on soil moisture, leaf area index, and vegetation dynamics. Solutions to further mitigate these challenges include integrating more advanced sensor technologies and increasing the spatial and temporal resolution of data collection through continuous monitoring and additional airborne remote sensing missions.
